metadata.title: California Water Permit Finder
metadata.description: Decision tree to help identify which California water permits you may need
metadata.disclaimer: This tool provides general guidance only. Always consult with your Regional Water Board for specific requirements.

start.title: What type of project or activity are you planning?
start.helpText: Select the category that best describes your project. If your project spans multiple categories, you may need multiple permits.

options.label: Industrial or Manufacturing
options.description: Factories, processing plants, warehouses with industrial operations

options.label: Agriculture or Farming
options.description: Crops, livestock, wineries, dairies, cannabis cultivation

options.label: Wastewater Treatment or Discharge
options.description: Sewage treatment, septic systems, industrial process water

options.label: Habitat Restoration
options.description: Stream restoration, wetland enhancement, invasive species removal

options.label: Water Diversion or Storage
options.description: Pumping from streams/rivers, reservoirs, wells, water storage

options.label: Dredging or Fill in Waterways
options.description: Placing fill in wetlands, streams, or coastal waters; dredging channels

construction_size.title: How much land will be disturbed?
construction_size.helpText: Include all clearing, grading, excavation, and demolition activities. Projects that are part of a larger development are considered together.

options.label: Less than 1 acre
options.description: Small projects, single lots, minor grading

construction_small_common_plan.title: Is this part of a larger common plan of development?
construction_small_common_plan.helpText: If your project is part of a phased development or subdivision that totals 1+ acres, the entire plan counts toward the threshold.

options.label: Yes, total plan is 1+ acres
options.description: Part of subdivision, phased project, or multiple lots

construction_waterway.title: Will your project involve work in or near waterways?
construction_waterway.helpText: This includes streams, wetlands, drainage channels, or flood control facilities.

options.label: Yes, work in or adjacent to waterways
options.description: Stream crossings, wetland impacts, drainage modifications

construction_surface_discharge.title: Where will stormwater from your site drain?
construction_surface_discharge.helpText: During and after construction, where does water leaving your site go?

options.label: To storm drains, streams, or other surface water

construction_risk_assessment.title: What is the terrain like?
construction_risk_assessment.helpText: This helps determine your risk level under the Construction General Permit.

construction_sensitive_waters.title: Does your site discharge to sensitive or impaired waters?
construction_sensitive_waters.helpText: Check the 303(d) list for your receiving water body. Sensitive waters include those with sediment TMDLs or habitat for endangered species.

options.label: Yes, water has TMDL or is impaired
options.description: Listed on 303(d) for sediment, nutrients, or other pollutants

industrial_discharge.title: What type of discharge does your facility have?
industrial_discharge.helpText: Consider both process wastewater and stormwater runoff from your site.

options.label: Stormwater runoff only
options.description: No process water discharge, just rain runoff from industrial areas

options.label: Process wastewater to surface water
options.description: Industrial process water discharged to streams, rivers, or ocean

options.label: Process wastewater to land
options.description: Discharge to evaporation ponds, land application, or infiltration

options.label: All discharge goes to public sewer

industrial_exposure.title: Are industrial materials exposed to stormwater?
industrial_exposure.helpText: Consider outdoor storage areas, loading docks, equipment storage, waste materials, and raw materials.

options.label: Yes, some industrial materials are outdoors
options.description: Storage areas, equipment, materials exposed to rain

options.label: No, all industrial activities are covered
options.description: Everything happens indoors or under cover

industrial_stormwater_check.title: Does stormwater from your site reach surface waters?
industrial_stormwater_check.helpText: Even if process water goes to sewer, stormwater from parking lots and outdoor areas may need a permit.

options.label: Yes, stormwater drains to storm system or surface water
options.description: Parking lot drains, roof drains to storm system

options.label: No, all runoff also goes to sanitary sewer

ag_type.title: What type of agricultural operation?
ag_type.helpText: Different agricultural activities have different permit pathways.

options.label: Winery or grape processing
options.description: Wine production, crush facilities, grape juice

winery_volume.title: How much process water does your winery generate annually?
winery_volume.helpText: This includes all wash water, crush water, and other process wastewater.

dairy_size.title: How many mature dairy cows?
dairy_size.helpText: This determines your facility classification and permit requirements.

dairy_discharge.title: Does wastewater discharge to surface waters?
dairy_discharge.helpText: Consider manure runoff, silage leachate, and other wastewater.

options.label: Yes, potential discharge to streams or ditches
options.description: Runoff leaves property to surface water

options.label: No, all waste contained on land
options.description: Lagoons, land application, no off-site discharge

cannabis_size.title: What is the size of your cannabis cultivation?
cannabis_size.helpText: Include all canopy area and disturbed area.

options.label: 2,000 sq ft to 1 acre disturbed area

ag_discharge.title: Is your agricultural land irrigated?
ag_discharge.helpText: In the Central Valley, virtually all irrigated agriculture requires WDR coverage.

options.label: Yes, crops are irrigated
options.description: Any form of irrigation water application

ag_region.title: Which region is your farm located in?
ag_region.helpText: Requirements vary significantly by Regional Water Board.

livestock_cafo.title: Does your facility meet CAFO thresholds?
livestock_cafo.helpText: Concentrated Animal Feeding Operations are defined by animal counts and confinement.

ww_destination.title: Where will your wastewater be discharged?
ww_destination.helpText: This is the primary factor in determining permit type.

ww_volume.title: What is your facility type and discharge volume?
ww_volume.helpText: This determines whether you need an individual permit or may qualify for a general permit.

ww_domestic_or_industrial.title: What type of wastewater?
ww_domestic_or_industrial.helpText: Domestic wastewater has different permit pathways than industrial.

domestic_volume.title: What is the daily wastewater flow?
domestic_volume.helpText: Average daily flow in gallons per day.

restoration_size.title: What is the size of your restoration project?
restoration_size.helpText: Different permit pathways exist based on project scale.

restoration_type.title: What type of restoration work?
restoration_type.helpText: The Statewide Restoration General Order covers specific project types.

options.label: Stream or fish passage improvement
options.description: Culvert replacement, fish ladder, dam removal

water_source.title: Where are you getting the water from?
water_source.helpText: Water rights requirements depend on the source.

water_right_type.title: What is your water rights situation?
water_right_type.helpText: California has different types of water rights with different requirements.

options.label: New diversion or no existing right
options.description: Need to establish new appropriative right

water_quantity.title: How much water do you need?
water_quantity.helpText: Small uses may qualify for streamlined registration programs.

municipal_type.title: What type of municipal operation?
municipal_type.helpText: Different municipal activities have different requirements.

municipal_population.title: What is the population served?
municipal_population.helpText: MS4 permit requirements are based on population thresholds.

municipal_urbanized.title: Is your community in a Census-defined urban area?
municipal_urbanized.helpText: Phase II requirements apply to small MS4s in urbanized areas ≥50,000 population.

dredge_federal.title: Will your project require a federal Section 404 permit?
dredge_federal.helpText: Section 404 of the Clean Water Act regulates discharge of dredged or fill material into waters of the United States.

options.label: Yes, 404 permit required
options.description: Fill in wetlands, streams, or navigable waters

dredge_water_type.title: What type of waterway is involved?
dredge_water_type.helpText: Federal jurisdiction typically includes navigable waters, their tributaries, and adjacent wetlands.

options.label: Stream or tributary to navigable water

result_small_construction_waterway.title: Construction Near Waterways - Special Requirements

permits.name: CDFW Lake and Streambed Alteration Agreement
permits.description: Required for any work that may change the bed, bank, or channel of a stream or lake.
permits.agency: California Department of Fish and Wildlife

permits.name: Section 401 Water Quality Certification
permits.description: May be required if federal Section 404 permit is needed for fill in waters.

result_small_construction_waterway.additionalInfo: Even projects under 1 acre may require permits if they affect streams or wetlands. Contact your Regional Board and CDFW early to determine specific requirements.
nextSteps: Contact your local CDFW regional office to discuss the project
Determine if the waterway is subject to federal jurisdiction
Consider consulting with a qualified biologist
result_small_construction_waterway.ragQuery: small construction project near streams waterways CDFW 1602 notification requirements

result_small_construction_no_permit.title: No Construction Stormwater Permit Required
result_small_construction_no_permit.additionalInfo: Projects under 1 acre that are not part of a larger development and don't affect waterways typically don't need a Construction General Permit. However, you must still comply with local erosion control requirements.
nextSteps: Check with your local city/county for grading permit requirements
Implement basic erosion control best management practices
Ensure no sediment leaves your site
result_small_construction_no_permit.ragQuery: small construction site erosion control best management practices California

result_cgp_level1.title: Construction General Permit - Risk Level 1

permits.name: Construction General Permit (CGP) - Risk Level 1
permits.description: Stormwater permit for construction sites ≥1 acre. Risk Level 1 has the lowest monitoring requirements.

requirements: Submit Notice of Intent (NOI) via SMARTS at least 1 month before construction
Develop and implement Stormwater Pollution Prevention Plan (SWPPP)
SWPPP must be prepared by Qualified SWPPP Developer (QSD)
Visual monitoring required (no sampling for Level 1)
nextSteps: Hire qualified QSD to develop SWPPP
Calculate risk level using SMARTS risk calculator
Install BMPs before land disturbance begins
result_cgp_level1.ragQuery: Construction General Permit CGP risk level 1 requirements SWPPP NOI SMARTS California

result_cgp_level2.title: Construction General Permit - Risk Level 2

permits.name: Construction General Permit (CGP) - Risk Level 2
permits.description: Stormwater permit for construction with moderate erosion risk. Requires water quality sampling during storm events.

requirements: Sampling required during qualifying rain events
Enhanced erosion and sediment control BMPs
Numeric Action Levels (NALs) for pH and turbidity
nextSteps: Hire QSD with experience in Risk Level 2 projects
Plan for water quality sampling during storms
result_cgp_level2.ragQuery: Construction General Permit CGP risk level 2 sampling requirements NAL California stormwater

result_cgp_level3.title: Construction General Permit - Risk Level 3

permits.name: Construction General Permit (CGP) - Risk Level 3
permits.description: Most stringent tier for high-risk sites discharging to sensitive waters. Numeric Effluent Limitations apply.

requirements: All Risk Level 1 and 2 requirements PLUS:
Minimum 3 samples per day during extended storms
Numeric Effluent Limitations (NELs) - exceedances are violations
Must demonstrate erosion doesn't exceed pre-construction levels
nextSteps: Engage experienced QSD early in design phase
Consider active treatment systems (may be required)
Budget significantly for monitoring and BMPs
Review applicable TMDLs for your watershed
Plan construction phasing to minimize exposed area
result_cgp_level3.ragQuery: Construction General Permit CGP risk level 3 NEL numeric effluent limitation TMDL sensitive waters California

result_igp.title: Industrial General Permit Required

permits.name: Industrial General Permit (IGP)
permits.description: Stormwater permit for industrial facilities with outdoor exposure of materials to rain.

requirements: Submit Notice of Intent (NOI) via SMARTS
Develop and implement Stormwater Pollution Prevention Plan (SWPPP)
Collect minimum 4 stormwater samples per year
Submit Annual Report by July 15 each year
Monitor against benchmark values for your industry
nextSteps: Determine your SIC code(s) from the IGP Attachment A
Register in SMARTS and submit NOI
Identify all discharge points and install BMPs
Train staff on pollution prevention procedures
result_igp.ragQuery: Industrial General Permit IGP SWPPP benchmark monitoring California stormwater SIC code

result_nec.title: No Exposure Certification Option

permits.name: No Exposure Certification (NEC)
permits.description: If ALL industrial materials and activities are protected from stormwater contact, you may certify no exposure instead of obtaining full IGP coverage.

requirements: ALL industrial materials and activities must be covered/protected
If any exposure develops, must immediately file NOI for full coverage
result_nec.additionalInfo: NEC is only available if you can truthfully certify no exposure in all 11 major exposure categories. One uncovered storage area or exposed equipment disqualifies your facility.
nextSteps: Conduct thorough site inspection of all 11 exposure categories
If qualified, submit NEC via SMARTS
result_nec.ragQuery: Industrial General Permit No Exposure Certification NEC eligibility criteria California

result_no_npdes_permit.title: No NPDES Permit Required
result_no_npdes_permit.additionalInfo: If your facility sends all process water AND stormwater to the sanitary sewer (combined system), you generally don't need an NPDES stormwater permit. However, you may have pretreatment requirements from your local sewer authority.
nextSteps: Confirm all drainage goes to sanitary sewer with your local POTW
Check if you need a local industrial pretreatment permit
result_no_npdes_permit.ragQuery: industrial pretreatment permit POTW sewer discharge California requirements

result_individual_npdes.title: Individual NPDES Permit Required

permits.name: Individual NPDES Permit
permits.description: A customized permit tailored to your specific discharge characteristics, issued by your Regional Water Board.
permits.fees: Varies by facility type and discharge

requirements: Submit federal EPA application forms (1, 2A-2F as applicable)
Technical report signed by registered civil engineer
result_individual_npdes.additionalInfo: Individual NPDES permits are complex and involve significant technical and regulatory review. Budget 6-12+ months for the process. Effluent limits will be based on technology standards and water quality objectives.
nextSteps: Contact your Regional Board for a pre-application meeting
Plan for compliance with anticipated permit limits
result_individual_npdes.ragQuery: individual NPDES permit application process California Regional Board Form 200 effluent limits

result_individual_wdr.title: Individual Waste Discharge Requirements Needed

permits.name: Individual WDR
permits.description: A customized permit for discharge to land or groundwater that doesn't fit a General Order category.
permits.fees: Varies by discharge type and region

requirements: Site map showing disposal areas, monitoring wells
nextSteps: Contact your Regional Board before submitting
Determine if any General Order might apply first
Assess groundwater conditions at your site
result_individual_wdr.ragQuery: individual WDR waste discharge requirements application California land discharge groundwater

result_winery_exempt.title: Winery Exempt from General Order
result_winery_exempt.additionalInfo: Wineries generating less than 10,000 gallons of process water annually are exempt from the Statewide Winery General Order, provided the discharge poses no threat to water quality. You should still follow best management practices.
nextSteps: Document your annual process water volume
Ensure no discharge to surface waters
Contact Regional Board if operations change
result_winery_exempt.ragQuery: small winery exempt California permit wastewater process water threshold

result_winery_tier1.title: Winery General Order - Tier 1

permits.name: Winery General Order - Tier 1
permits.description: For wineries generating 10,000-30,000 gallons process water annually. Basic requirements with minimal monitoring.

requirements: Submit Notice of Intent to Regional Board
Implement basic BMPs for wastewater management
Maintain records of process water volumes
No discharge to surface waters allowed
nextSteps: Prepare NOI with basic facility information
Implement land application or other approved disposal method
result_winery_tier1.ragQuery: winery general order tier 1 California NOI requirements process wastewater

result_winery_tier2.title: Winery General Order - Tier 2

permits.name: Winery General Order - Tier 2
permits.description: For wineries generating 30,000-300,000 gallons process water annually. Moderate monitoring requirements.

nextSteps: Submit NOI with detailed facility information
Plan disposal areas with appropriate buffer zones
result_winery_tier2.ragQuery: winery general order tier 2 California wastewater monitoring requirements

result_winery_tier3.title: Winery General Order - Tier 3

permits.name: Winery General Order - Tier 3
permits.description: For wineries generating 300,000-1,000,000 gallons process water annually. Comprehensive monitoring required.

result_winery_tier3.ragQuery: winery general order tier 3 California nitrogen control plan groundwater monitoring

result_winery_tier4.title: Winery General Order - Tier 4

permits.name: Winery General Order - Tier 4
permits.description: For large wineries generating 1-15 million gallons process water annually. Full monitoring with groundwater wells required.

result_winery_tier4.additionalInfo: Wineries generating over 15 million gallons annually exceed the General Order threshold and need individual WDRs.
nextSteps: Engage environmental consultant for monitoring program design
result_winery_tier4.ragQuery: winery general order tier 4 California groundwater monitoring wells large facility

result_dairy_large.title: Large Dairy - CAFO Requirements

permits.name: Dairy General Order (Regional)
permits.description: Large dairies (700+ mature cows) are classified as Large CAFOs with the most stringent requirements.

requirements: No discharge to surface waters (must fully contain all waste)
May need NPDES permit if any discharge occurs
result_dairy_large.additionalInfo: Large CAFOs that discharge to surface waters require NPDES permits in addition to WDRs. Zero discharge is the goal.
nextSteps: Contact your Regional Board (typically Region 5 for Central Valley)
Develop Nutrient Management Plan with qualified professional
Ensure waste storage capacity for storm events
result_dairy_large.ragQuery: large dairy CAFO California permit nutrient management waste management plan Region 5

result_dairy_npdes.title: Dairy with Surface Water Discharge

permits.name: NPDES Permit (CAFO)
permits.description: Dairies that discharge to surface waters need NPDES coverage in addition to WDRs.

permits.name: Dairy General Order (WDR)
permits.description: Separate WDR coverage for land application of waste.

requirements: Zero discharge should be goal - NPDES is for when discharge occurs
nextSteps: Evaluate options to eliminate surface water discharge
If discharge unavoidable, prepare NPDES application
result_dairy_npdes.ragQuery: dairy NPDES permit surface water discharge California CAFO requirements

result_dairy_general.title: Dairy General Order

permits.name: Dairy General Order
permits.description: Coverage for dairy operations that contain all waste on-site with no discharge to surface waters.

requirements: Maintain zero discharge to surface waters
nextSteps: Determine which Regional Board has jurisdiction
Prepare Nutrient and Waste Management Plans
Establish monitoring and record keeping systems
result_dairy_general.ragQuery: dairy general order California nutrient management plan waste management WDR enrollment

result_cannabis_exempt.title: Cannabis Cultivation - Exempt
result_cannabis_exempt.additionalInfo: Personal/medical cannabis cultivation under 2,000 square feet of canopy is generally exempt from the Cannabis Cultivation General Order. However, you may still need local permits and a cannabis license.
result_cannabis_exempt.ragQuery: cannabis cultivation exempt California personal medical use canopy threshold

result_cannabis_tier1_standard.title: Cannabis General Order - Tier 1 Standard Risk

permits.name: Cannabis Cultivation General Order - Tier 1
permits.description: For cannabis cultivation with 2,000 sq ft to 1 acre disturbed area in standard risk locations.

requirements: Proof of water right or exemption
result_cannabis_tier1_standard.ragQuery: cannabis cultivation general order tier 1 California site management plan water rights

result_cannabis_tier1_high.title: Cannabis General Order - Tier 1 High Risk

permits.name: Cannabis Cultivation General Order - Tier 1 High Risk
permits.description: For cannabis cultivation on steep slopes or near waterways. Enhanced requirements apply.

nextSteps: Verify setback requirements for your location
Consider site modifications to reduce risk
Engage qualified professional for erosion control design
result_cannabis_tier1_high.ragQuery: cannabis cultivation high risk steep slopes stream setback California requirements

result_cannabis_tier2.title: Cannabis General Order - Tier 2

permits.name: Cannabis Cultivation General Order - Tier 2
permits.description: For large cannabis operations (>1 acre) or indoor facilities of any size.

nextSteps: Evaluate TMDL requirements for your watershed
Ensure water rights documentation is complete
result_cannabis_tier2.ragQuery: cannabis cultivation tier 2 large operation California general order monitoring TMDL

result_ag_no_permit.title: Dryland Agriculture - Generally No Permit
result_ag_no_permit.additionalInfo: Dryland (non-irrigated) farming generally doesn't require WDR coverage. However, if your practices could affect water quality (such as heavy pesticide use near waterways), you may still need coverage.
nextSteps: Monitor if practices change to include irrigation
result_ag_no_permit.ragQuery: dryland agriculture California permit requirements nonpoint source pollution

result_ilrp.title: Irrigated Lands Regulatory Program (Central Valley)

permits.name: ILRP General Order Coverage
permits.description: All irrigated agriculture in the Central Valley must have WDR coverage, either individually or through a third-party coalition.

requirements: Join a third-party coalition OR obtain individual WDR
Implement Irrigation and Nitrogen Management Plan
result_ilrp.additionalInfo: Most growers join coalitions like ESJWQC, SJREC, or Sacramento Valley for cost-effective compliance. Coalitions provide technical assistance and coordinate monitoring.
nextSteps: Contact an agricultural coalition in your area
Submit enrollment forms to chosen coalition
result_ilrp.ragQuery: irrigated lands regulatory program ILRP California Central Valley coalition enrollment nitrogen management

result_ag_order_r3.title: Central Coast Agricultural Order

permits.name: Agricultural Order
permits.description: Irrigated agriculture in the Central Coast region requires coverage under the Agricultural Order.

nextSteps: Determine your tier level based on operation characteristics
result_ag_order_r3.ragQuery: Central Coast agricultural order California Region 3 irrigated agriculture enrollment

result_contact_regional_board.title: Contact Your Regional Water Board
result_contact_regional_board.additionalInfo: Your specific situation doesn't clearly fit a standard category. Contact your Regional Water Board directly for guidance on permit requirements.
nextSteps: Determine which Regional Board has jurisdiction (based on location)
Prepare a summary of your operation and proposed discharge
result_contact_regional_board.ragQuery: Regional Water Board contact permit requirements California guidance

result_cafo_npdes.title: Large CAFO - NPDES Required

permits.name: NPDES CAFO Permit
permits.description: Large Concentrated Animal Feeding Operations require NPDES permit coverage.

requirements: Zero discharge required in most cases
nextSteps: Contact Regional Board for specific requirements
result_cafo_npdes.ragQuery: CAFO NPDES permit California concentrated animal feeding operation requirements

result_afo_wdr.title: Animal Feeding Operation - WDR Coverage

permits.name: WDR General Order or Individual
permits.description: Medium animal feeding operations with discharge potential need WDR coverage.

nextSteps: Contact Regional Board to determine specific requirements
Evaluate options to contain all runoff on-site
Submit NOI or application as directed
result_afo_wdr.ragQuery: animal feeding operation AFO WDR California waste management containment

result_no_wdr_pretreatment.title: No WDR Needed - Check Pretreatment Requirements
result_no_wdr_pretreatment.additionalInfo: Discharges to public sewer don't require WDRs because the POTW holds the NPDES permit. However, you may need a local pretreatment permit from your sewer agency.
nextSteps: Determine if industrial pretreatment permit required
result_no_wdr_pretreatment.ragQuery: industrial pretreatment permit local sewer discharge POTW California

result_potw_npdes.title: POTW - Individual NPDES Permit

permits.name: Individual NPDES Permit (POTW)
permits.description: Publicly Owned Treatment Works require individual NPDES permits with specific secondary treatment standards.
permits.fees: Based on flow and discharge type

requirements: Pretreatment program (if >5 MGD with industrial users)
result_potw_npdes.additionalInfo: POTWs must meet federal secondary treatment standards and may have more stringent water quality-based limits depending on receiving water.
nextSteps: Submit renewal application 180 days before expiration
Review receiving water conditions for potential WQBELs
Plan for any necessary treatment upgrades
result_potw_npdes.ragQuery: POTW NPDES permit California secondary treatment standards pretreatment program

result_septic_tier1.title: Onsite Wastewater - Tier 1

permits.name: OWTS Tier 1 (Local Oversight)
permits.description: Standard residential septic systems under 3,500 GPD are regulated locally under the statewide OWTS Policy.

requirements: Local permit from county environmental health
Proper setbacks from wells and waterways
result_septic_tier1.additionalInfo: Most residential septic systems are permitted locally under the State Water Board's OWTS Policy. Contact your county environmental health department.
nextSteps: Contact your county environmental health department
Have system designed by qualified professional
result_septic_tier1.ragQuery: septic system OWTS tier 1 California local permit county environmental health

result_septic_tier2.title: Onsite Wastewater - Tier 2

permits.name: OWTS Tier 2 (LAMP Area)
permits.description: Systems in areas with Local Agency Management Programs may have additional requirements or alternative standards.

nextSteps: Check if your county has a LAMP
result_septic_tier2.ragQuery: OWTS tier 2 LAMP California onsite wastewater alternative system

result_small_domestic_wdr.title: Small Community Wastewater System

permits.name: Small Domestic Wastewater General Order
permits.description: For systems serving multiple residences or small commercial facilities with flows between 10,000-100,000 GPD.

nextSteps: Determine if system qualifies for General Order
result_small_domestic_wdr.ragQuery: small domestic wastewater general order California community system 10000 GPD

result_low_threat.title: Low-Threat Discharge General Order

permits.name: Low-Threat Discharge General Order
permits.description: For clean or relatively pollutant-free wastewaters like pool drainage, construction dewatering, or hydrant flushing.

requirements: Characterize discharge to confirm low-threat status
result_low_threat.additionalInfo: Low-threat orders are tiered (1A, 1B, 2, 3) based on treatment needed. Contact your Regional Board to confirm eligibility.
nextSteps: Contact Regional Board for specific requirements
result_low_threat.ragQuery: low threat discharge general order California clean water dewatering pool drainage

result_small_restoration.title: Small Habitat Restoration Order

permits.name: General Order for Small Habitat Restoration Projects
permits.description: Streamlined 401 certification for restoration projects ≤5 acres or ≤500 linear feet.
permits.estimatedTime: 30 days (or deemed approved if no response)

requirements: Submit NOI at least 30 days before project start
Project must meet CEQA categorical exemption criteria
Basic project description and protection measures
result_small_restoration.additionalInfo: Small restoration projects receive streamlined permitting. You may also qualify for CDFW's HREA (1652/1653) for expedited Lake and Streambed Alteration coverage.
nextSteps: Confirm project meets size and eligibility criteria
Coordinate with CDFW for 1600 agreement if needed
result_small_restoration.ragQuery: small habitat restoration order California 401 certification streamlined permit

result_srgo.title: Statewide Restoration General Order (SRGO)

permits.name: Statewide Restoration General Order
permits.description: Unified 401 certification and WDR coverage for restoration projects >5 acres with net ecological benefit.

requirements: Submit NOI with project description, maps, baseline conditions
Project must result in net increase in aquatic/riparian functions
result_srgo.additionalInfo: SRGO covers 10 specific project types including stream restoration, wetland creation, dam removal, and invasive species removal. Significantly faster than individual permits.
nextSteps: Request pre-application meeting with Regional Board
Prepare NOI package with required elements
Coordinate with Army Corps (404), CDFW (1600), and other agencies
result_srgo.ragQuery: Statewide Restoration General Order SRGO California habitat restoration 401 certification

result_groundwater_rights.title: Groundwater Rights
result_groundwater_rights.additionalInfo: Groundwater rights in California are primarily managed locally through Groundwater Sustainability Agencies (GSAs) under SGMA. You generally don't need a State Water Board permit to pump groundwater, but local restrictions may apply.
requirements: Check if your basin is subject to SGMA (medium or high priority)
Contact your local GSA for pumping rules
May need well permit from county
May be subject to adjudication in some basins
result_groundwater_rights.ragQuery: groundwater rights California SGMA GSA pumping permit well

result_no_water_right_needed.title: No Water Right Needed - Purchasing Water
result_no_water_right_needed.additionalInfo: If you're purchasing water from a water district, utility, or municipal supplier, the supplier already has the water rights. You don't need your own water right permit.
nextSteps: Establish account with your water supplier
Understand any use restrictions in your service agreement
For large uses, confirm supplier has adequate supply
result_no_water_right_needed.ragQuery: water supply contract California water district municipal supplier

result_recycled_water.title: Recycled Water Use
result_recycled_water.additionalInfo: Recycled water use is regulated through the producer's permit. As a user, you may need to enter a recycled water use agreement and follow specific use requirements.
requirements: Recycled water use agreement with producer
Follow approved use categories (landscape, agriculture, industrial)
nextSteps: Determine approved uses for the water quality
Install required signage and backflow prevention
result_recycled_water.ragQuery: recycled water use California Title 22 user requirements agreement

result_riparian.title: Riparian Water Right
result_riparian.additionalInfo: Riparian rights arise automatically from owning land adjacent to a natural water source. No permit is required, but you must still use water reasonably and beneficially.
requirements: Land must physically touch the water source
Use limited to natural flow (no storage)
Water must be used on riparian land (same watershed)
Must file Statement of Water Diversion and Use if diverting >10 AF/year
Subject to correlative sharing during shortages
nextSteps: Confirm your land qualifies as riparian
File Statement of Water Diversion and Use with State Water Board
Implement reasonable and beneficial use practices
result_riparian.ragQuery: riparian water rights California statement of diversion reasonable beneficial use

result_pre1914.title: Pre-1914 Appropriative Right
result_pre1914.additionalInfo: Pre-1914 appropriative rights are vested rights that don't require a permit. However, recent legislation (SB 389) gives the State Water Board investigative and enforcement authority.
requirements: Must document history of use since before December 19, 1914
File Statement of Water Diversion and Use annually
Subject to reasonable and beneficial use requirement
May receive information orders from State Water Board
nextSteps: File Statement of Water Diversion and Use
Respond to any State Water Board inquiries
result_pre1914.ragQuery: pre-1914 water right California appropriative vested statement diversion SB 389

result_small_domestic_registration.title: Small Domestic Use Registration

permits.name: Small Domestic Use Registration
permits.description: Streamlined registration for small domestic water use up to 4,500 gallons per day.
permits.agency: State Water Resources Control Board - Division of Water Rights

requirements: No injury to other legal users

result_small_irrigation_registration.title: Small Irrigation Use Registration

permits.name: Small Irrigation Use Registration
permits.description: Streamlined registration for small-scale agricultural irrigation.
permits.agency: State Water Resources Control Board - Division of Water Rights

requirements: No injury to other legal users
nextSteps: Document place and purpose of use

result_stockpond_registration.title: Livestock Stockpond Registration

permits.name: Livestock Stockpond Registration
permits.description: Registration for impoundments used to water livestock.
permits.agency: State Water Resources Control Board - Division of Water Rights

requirements: Dam must meet Division of Safety of Dams requirements if applicable
nextSteps: Confirm pond is for livestock only
result_stockpond_registration.ragQuery: livestock stockpond registration California water right cattle

result_appropriative_permit.title: Appropriative Water Right Permit Required

permits.name: Post-1914 Appropriative Water Right Permit
permits.description: Full application process for new water diversions from streams, rivers, or lakes.
permits.agency: State Water Resources Control Board - Division of Water Rights

requirements: May require formal hearing if protested
Permit phase, then license phase after beneficial use demonstrated
result_appropriative_permit.additionalInfo: Water rights permits are complex and take years. Consider consulting a water rights attorney. Not all applications are approved—water must be available.
nextSteps: Prepare complete application with technical documentation
result_appropriative_permit.ragQuery: appropriative water right permit application California Division of Water Rights process timeline

result_ms4_phase1.title: MS4 Phase I Permit Required

permits.name: Phase I MS4 Permit (Regional)
permits.description: Regional permit for large municipal storm sewer systems serving populations ≥100,000.

result_ms4_phase1.additionalInfo: Large MS4s are typically already covered under regional permits with multiple co-permittees. Your jurisdiction should already have a permit in place.
nextSteps: Review permit requirements and compliance schedules
result_ms4_phase1.ragQuery: MS4 Phase I permit California municipal stormwater management plan MEP TMDL

result_ms4_phase2.title: MS4 Phase II Permit Required

permits.name: Phase II Small MS4 General Permit
permits.description: Statewide general permit for small MS4s in urbanized areas with population ≥50,000.

result_ms4_phase2.ragQuery: MS4 Phase II permit California small MS4 general permit six minimum control measures MCM

result_no_ms4_permit.title: MS4 Permit May Not Be Required
result_no_ms4_permit.additionalInfo: Rural communities not in Census-defined urbanized areas may not need MS4 permit coverage. However, you should implement stormwater best practices.
nextSteps: Confirm your community is not in an urbanized area
Verify no designation by Regional Board
result_no_ms4_permit.ragQuery: rural community stormwater California urbanized area MS4 exemption

result_401_certification.title: Section 401 Water Quality Certification Required

permits.name: Section 401 Water Quality Certification
permits.description: State certification that your federally-permitted project will comply with water quality standards.
permits.agency: Regional Water Quality Control Board (or State Board for FERC/multi-regional)
permits.fees: Based on project type and impact area

permits.name: Section 404 Permit
permits.description: Federal permit for discharge of dredged or fill material (obtained from Army Corps).

requirements: Request pre-filing meeting at least 30 days before application
result_401_certification.additionalInfo: You cannot receive a federal permit (404, FERC, etc.) without state 401 certification. California can grant, condition, or deny certification.
nextSteps: Apply for federal Section 404 permit from Army Corps
Request pre-filing meeting with Regional Board
Coordinate timing between federal and state processes
result_401_certification.ragQuery: 401 certification California Section 404 dredge fill Army Corps federal permit

result_wdr_dredge_fill.title: WDR for Dredge/Fill in State Waters

permits.name: WDR for Dredge or Fill
permits.description: For dredge/fill activities in waters of the state that are not subject to federal jurisdiction.

result_wdr_dredge_fill.additionalInfo: After the Supreme Court's 2023 Sackett decision, some waters lost federal protection but remain waters of the state under Porter-Cologne. WDRs apply to impacts in these areas.
nextSteps: Determine if waters are truly non-federal
Consider CDFW Lake and Streambed Alteration requirements
result_wdr_dredge_fill.ragQuery: WDR dredge fill state waters California Sackett isolated wetlands Porter-Cologne
